- VS Code Version: 1.103.2
- OS Version: macOS Sequoia

Steps to Reproduce

README.md:

```text
           _
          | |
 ___  __ _| | _____
/ __|/ _` | |/ / _ \
\__ \ (_| |   <  __/
|___/\__,_|_|\_\___|
```

The left parenthesis (`(`) in the center of the a in sake ASCII text art is strangely highlighted in red, in a plain text language (GitHub flavored) Markdown block.

I believe this is due to VSCode overeagerly enforcing parenthesis balancing, that shouldn't apply to plain text files, nor plain text language codeblocks in Markdown or other document formats.

title: references-view: removeReferenceItem hotkey implementation
body:
Resolves #234017 and #200465.

Previously ```removeReferenceItem``` did not function when utilized via hotkey. This is because the function called by the hotkey does not have the "item" to remove.  
This is resolved by iterating over the current selection and calling remove on those items in the case where no item is provided.

This can be tested by:
* Assigning a hotkey to removeReferenceItem
* Right clicking on a symbol and selecting "Find All References"
* Pressing the hotkey

title: Inline expandable comments for code lines

labels.name: *extension-candidate
labels.description: Issue identified as good extension implementation

body:
Problem
When writing code, short inline comments near variables are often not enough to explain their purpose. On the other hand, long comments make the code harder to read and clutter the file.

Proposed Solution
Introduce a mechanism to attach markdown-formatted descriptions to specific lines of code, similar to how GitHub allows comments on pull requests. These comments could be indicated by a small icon next to the line number (similar to breakpoints or Git change markers). By default, they would stay hidden to keep the code clean, but could expand on click to show a more detailed explanation.

These inline comments should also be stored inside the repository in a hidden folder (similar to .git), so that other collaborators can read and edit them as well.

title: Explorer: add `explorer.collapseResource` to collapse a specific folder (by URI) without changing focus (#261598)
body:
## Summary
Adds two new commands `explorer.collapseResource` and `explorer.collapseResourceRecursive` that collapses a specific folder (and it's child folders with the recurscive command) in the Explorer given its resource URI, without changing focus/selection.

## Motivation
Extensions and automation need to collapse folders programmatically without UI flicker or stealing focus. Existing commands operate only on the focused element. This would allow the development of an extension which keeps the explorer tidy.

## Implementation
- Registers `explorer.collapseResource` (args: `URI`).
- Registers `explorer.collapseResourceRecursive` (args: `URI`).
- No behavior change to existing commands.

## Backwards compatibility
- New commands only; no changes to existing public commands.

## Related
Fixes #261598

title: Add notification badge support to ChatSessionItem in VS Code chat sessions
body:
This PR implements notification badge support for individual chat session items in VS Code's chat sessions view pane, enabling chat session providers (like coding agents) to display notification badges when sessions require user attention.

## Problem

Chat session providers had no way to indicate when sessions needed attention or had updates. For example, a coding agent completing a task couldn't notify users that results were ready for review.

## Solution

Added `badge` and `badgeTooltip` properties to the `ChatSessionItem` interface, allowing extensions to display notification badges with numeric counts or text indicators.

### Key Features

- **Flexible badge content**: Support for both numeric badges (`5`) and text badges (`"NEW"`, `"●"`)
- **Visual positioning**: Badges appear between the session label and actions for optimal visibility
- **Backward compatibility**: Existing sessions work unchanged - badges are optional
- **VS Code design consistency**: Uses standard badge colors (`--vscode-badge-background`, `--vscode-badge-foreground`)
- **Accessibility**: Full tooltip support and high contrast theme compatibility

### Example Usage

Extensions can now provide badge information when creating or updating chat sessions:

```typescript
// Numeric badge for message count
{
  id: 'code-review-session',
  label: 'Code Review Chat',
  badge: 5,
  badgeTooltip: '5 new messages'
}

// Text badge for status
{
  id: 'bug-fix-session', 
  label: 'Bug Fix Assistant',
  badge: 'COMPLETE',
  badgeTooltip: 'Task completed - review results'
}
```

## Implementation

The implementation follows VS Code's minimal-change approach:

1. **Core interface**: Extended `IChatSessionItem` with optional `badge?: string | number` and `badgeTooltip?: string` properties
2. **Extension API**: Added corresponding properties to the proposed `ChatSessionItem` interface
3. **Extension host**: Updated conversion to pass badge properties through
4. **Renderer**: Extended template to create badge elements and show/hide based on data
5. **Styling**: Added CSS following VS Code's badge design patterns

All changes maintain full backward compatibility - sessions without badges display exactly as before.

## Files Changed

- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/common/chatSessionsService.ts` - Core interface extension
- `src/vscode-dts/vscode.proposed.chatSessionsProvider.d.ts` - Extension API types  
- `src/vs/workbench/api/common/extHostChatSessions.ts` - Extension host conversion
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/chatSessions.ts` - Renderer implementation
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/media/chatSessions.css` - Badge styling

title: Fix editor edge clicking
body:
When clicking the 10 left-most pixels of the editor, the cursor was moved to the beginning of the line. When clicking the 10 right-most characters of the editor, the cursor was moved to the end of the line. This is not correct in RTL. Clicking the left pixels should move the cursor to the left. Clicking the right pixels should move the cursor to the right.

This was an oversight in #255455.

Also the `horizontalScrollPadding` is hardcoded to 10. I noticed in my own editor this means I can’t put the cursor between the first two characters in VSCode. It will always snap to the beginning of the line. Should this be made configurable (in a separate PR)?

title: disconnects every time it runs a command
After VSCode update inside of devcontainer `gzip` produces files with chmod `200` in mounted folder

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->

### Environment

- Host OS: macOS 14.5 (APFS)
- VSCode Version: 1.103.0
- Dev Containers extension version: 0.422.1
- Docker Desktop version: 4.37.2 (179585) / also tried 4.44.3 (202357)
- Container OS: Ubuntu 20.04 and 24.04 (repro with stock image)
- gzip version inside container: gzip 1.10
- mount type (from mount): 
```
/run/host_mark/Users on /workspaces/... type fakeowner (rw,nosuid,nodev,relatime,fakeowner)
```

### Description
After updating VSCode, I noticed that running `gzip` inside my Ubuntu devcontainer now produces compressed files with an unexpected and unusable mode (`200` = write-only, no read/exec). This makes the file inaccessible from inside the container until I manually fix permissions from the macOS host.

This did **not** happen before the update. Nothing changed in the container image or tooling.

Other compressors like `brotli` behave normally.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a devcontainer workspace located in `/workspaces/...` (host-mounted volume).
2. Inside the container:
```
echo "hello" > app.wasm
chmod 755 app.wasm
gzip -2 -f --keep app.wasm
ls -l app.wasm.gz
```
3. Observe the file mode of `app.wasm.gz`.

### Expected

`app.wasm.gz` should have mode derived from input file and umask, e.g.:
```
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root  XX Aug 22  app.wasm.gz
```
(on macOS host it is `755`, on Linux containers normally `644` or similar).

### Actual

Inside the devcontainer workspace mount:
```
---w------- 1 root root XX Aug 22 app.wasm.gz
```
(chmod 200)

- File is not readable inside the container.
- Attempting to `chmod` inside the container does not work (permissions remain `200`).
- The same command run in `/tmp` (ext4 inside container) produces correct chmod (`600`).
- Brotli (`brotli app.wasm`) produces chmod `600` correctly in both cases.

### Analysis

- `umask` is normal (`0022`).
- Input file (`app.wasm`) has mode `755`.
- Issue only occurs on volumes mounted with `type=fakeowner`.
- Likely a regression in how the **fakeowner** implementation maps POSIX file modes between macOS host and container after the VSCode update.
- Since gzip preserves execute bits, the chmod translation seems to strip read/exec incorrectly, resulting in chmod `200`.

### Workaround

- Compress to `/tmp` inside the container and copy the result back:
```
gzip -2 -f -c app.wasm > /tmp/app.wasm.gz && cp /tmp/app.wasm.gz .
```

### Impact

- Breaks standard build workflows (`gzip` is a common step in web builds).
- Leads to unreadable artifacts inside the container unless patched manually from host.

### Request

Please investigate the regression that causes tools like `gzip` to produce unreadable files (chmod `200`).

Added unit tests to cover both cases.

title: Prompt Queue for Copilot Chat

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
# **Current Behavior**
In Copilot Chat, sending a new message while Copilot is still generating cancels the ongoing response. This creates friction when working on multi-step coding tasks, since users often think of additional instructions mid-run but don’t want to interrupt.

# **Problem**

* Users must either wait for Copilot to finish before adding input, or interrupt and risk breaking the flow.
* Quick follow-up ideas can be lost if the user doesn’t manually note them down.
* Long tasks (e.g., refactoring, scaffolding multiple files) become inefficient without a way to line up refinements.

# **Proposed Solution**
Introduce a **Prompt Queue** system:

* Allow users to add follow-up prompts to a queue while Copilot is still working.
* After Copilot finishes the current generation, queued prompts are processed in order.
* UI could show queued prompts in a lightweight panel or expandable area.
* Support actions like:

  * Queue instead of send (`Ctrl+Shift+Enter`)
  * Reorder or delete queued prompts
  * See a count of pending prompts

# **Optional Enhancements**

* Queue persists for the current chat session.
* “Send immediately” option still available for urgent cases.
* Mid-run comments: Copilot can occasionally check the queue for hints during long tasks without a full interruption.

# **Benefits**

* Prevents disruption of long or complex responses.
* Keeps user thoughts captured and actionable without context switching.
* Increases productivity for workflows involving sequential refinements.

title: rewrite polling function
body:
This PR refactors the OutputMonitor polling functionality to use an event-driven approach instead of promise-based monitoring. The changes move from a `startMonitoring()` method that returns a result to one that fires events and exposes results via properties.
- Replace promise-based polling with event-driven monitoring that fires `onDidFinishCommand` events
- Restructure the constructor to automatically start monitoring and accept monitoring parameters

Enables us to easily monitor foreground terminals

title: Stuck on "Installing Update..."
body:
Type: Bug 1. Do a clean uninstall of VSCode. 2. Install VSCode. 3. Use VSCode regularly until it tries to update. 4. VSCode gets stuck on "Installing Update..." 5. Closing VSCode and opening it again shows the Setup dialog from #62476 Workaround: 1. Open task manager once you're on "Installing Update..." and have given it some time to update. 2. title: Add granular telemetry for terminal tool input interactions and remove deprecated autoReplyCount field
body:
This PR adds comprehensive granular telemetry fields to track user interactions with AI-generated suggestions and auto-responses across all terminal tools that use `collectTerminalResults`, while cleaning up deprecated telemetry fields.

## Problem

The current telemetry for terminal tools only provided basic metrics like `autoReplyCount` and `inputUserChars`. We needed more detailed insights into how users interact with AI-generated suggestions and how much input is handled automatically vs manually across all task execution tools.

## Solution

Added 4 new active telemetry fields to capture granular interaction data across **all terminal tools**:

- **`inputToolManualAcceptCount`** - How many times the user clicked to accept a detected suggestion
- **`inputToolManualRejectCount`** - How many times the user rejected a detected suggestion  
- **`inputToolManualChars`** - Character count from inputs accepted manually by the user
- **`inputToolSuggestChars`** - Character count for input suggested by copilot
- **`inputToolSuggestInputCount`** - How many times Copilot suggested input

## Implementation

The telemetry tracking is implemented consistently across all tools that interact with terminals:

1. **RunInTerminalTool** - Already had the foundation, enhanced with new fields
2. **RunTaskTool** - Added complete telemetry with new granular fields
3. **CreateAndRunTaskTool** - Added complete telemetry with new granular fields
4. **GetTaskOutputTool** - Added telemetry infrastructure and new granular fields

The data flows through the existing telemetry pipeline: `OutputMonitor` → `IPollingResult` → Task Tools → respective telemetry events.

## Breaking Changes

- Removed the deprecated `autoReplyCount` field from `IPollingResult` interface and related implementations as it's no longer used by any tools

## Benefits

This comprehensive telemetry will help understand:
- User acceptance rates for AI suggestions across different tool types
- Effectiveness of manual input handling mechanisms in various contexts
- Balance between automatic vs manual input handling per tool
- Areas for improving the suggestion system across the terminal tool ecosystem

All new fields follow proper GDPR classification as `SystemMetaData` with `FeatureInsight` purpose.

Fixes #262928.

<!-- START COPILOT CODING AGENT TIPS -->
---

✨ Let Copilot coding agent [set things up for you](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?title=✨+Set+up+Copilot+instructions&body=Configure%20instructions%20for%20this%20repository%20as%20documented%20in%20%5BBest%20practices%20for%20Copilot%20coding%20agent%20in%20your%20repository%5D%28https://gh.io/copilot-coding-agent-tips%29%2E%0A%0A%3COnboard%20this%20repo%3E&assignees=copilot) — coding agent works faster and does higher quality work when set up for your repo.

title: GPT-5 Mini (Preview) shows as a free (0x) model but IT IS NOT.
body: This is a reopen of #262921 because the bot mis-identified this as being related to https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/252230 and auto-closed it. - Copilot Chat Extension Version: 1.360.1752 - VS Code Version: 1.103.1 - OS Version: Win 11 - Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): Agent - Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): GPT-5 Mini - Logs: But using it results in: ``` You have exceeded your premium request allowance. We have automatically switched you to GPT-4.1 which is included with your plan. Enable additional paid premium requests to continue using premium models. ``` And the debug panel confirms that 4.1 was used to process the request instead of 5 mini. Most importantly, it is being billed at a non-zero rate (e.g. at https://github.com/settings/billing/usage), because I ran out premium requests a few minutes ago after having exclusively been using gpt-5 mini for the past ~hour.

title: 3 Way Merge Editor issue with git subtree

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: git
labels.description: GIT issues

body: I have the same issue but with `git subtree` do you want me to create another thread? I can confirm `JetBrain Fleet` and `GitKraken` shows the merge editor properly My `root/client` is a git subtree of my upstream, but i also have a `root/server` which is my own code. I have used the following commands to set it up ### Initial setup from my open source upstream ```bash git remote add upstream https://github.com/OHIF/Viewers.git git fetch upstream release/3.10 git subtree add --prefix=client upstream release/3.10 ``` this will add the code to a new client folder Then for update to 3.11 I do ```bash git fetch upstream release/3.11 git subtree pull --prefix=client upstream release/3.11 ``` which cause conflict but that is expected, i need to resolve them. For instance if you see in the conflict list the `TooltipShowcase.tsx` it shows with this error message ``` Unable to read file 'git:/Users/alireza/open-source/temp/client/platform/docs/src/pages/components/TooltipShowcase.tsx?{"path":"/Users/alireza/open-source/temp/client/platform/docs/src/pages/components/TooltipShowcase.tsx","ref":"522531cc5c97ed05470f55a7a8f6571d9a512bd4"}' (Error: Unable to resolve nonexistent file 'git:/Users/alireza/open-source/temp/client/platform/docs/src/pages/components/TooltipShowcase.tsx?{"path":"/Users/alireza/open-source/temp/client/platform/docs/src/pages/components/TooltipShowcase.tsx","ref":"522531cc5c97ed05470f55a7a8f6571d9a512bd4"}') ``` Interestingly enough if i click on the file itself it shows the old merge edit, but i'm intereseted in the 3 way editor - VS Code Version: Version: 1.103.2 (Universal) - OS Version: macOS
